title: All small buttons should have a height of 24 (minimum click-target for a11y)

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

body:
Today the 'small' button size has a height of 22px with 11px left- and right-padding. 
To meet minimum click target size requirements, we need the button to be 24px high. 
I believe we can keep the size of the font and other elements within the button the same, and just have a slightly bigger top- and bottom-padding.

title: Update tool confirmation buttons to size 'small'

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

body: Currently the tool call confirmation uses the 'default' button size (28px high). To address button inconsistencies while working in chat and reviewing code (#261472 ) we'd like to make the tool confirmation size "small". The small button has a height of 22px with 11px left- and right-padding. Mock of the tool call confirmation with small size: Separately, the small button height needs to be updated from 22px to 24px to meet accessibility requirements for a minimum click-target size.

title: Fix chat disclaimer padding for responsive design
body:
Fixes insufficient padding in chat disclaimer messages when there's no chat history, improving readability at narrow viewport widths.

## Problem

The chat disclaimer welcome messages (e.g., "AI responses may be inaccurate.") had inadequate horizontal padding, causing text to appear uncomfortably close to container edges, especially on narrow screens. The issue was particularly noticeable in the empty chat state where disclaimers are positioned absolutely at the bottom of the container.

![Chat disclaimer with insufficient padding](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6468e492-2b05-4f04-ae61-7eea13831ba6)

## Root Cause

1. **Fixed padding was too small**: Used `padding: 0 8px` which is insufficient for mobile/narrow viewports
2. **Missing padding property**: The no-chat-history disclaimer state completely lacked a padding declaration
3. **No responsive scaling**: Padding didn't adapt to different screen sizes, causing poor UX on mobile devices

## Solution

Replaced fixed padding with responsive padding using CSS `max()` function:

```css
/* Before */
padding: 0 8px;

/* After */  
padding: 0 max(12px, 2.5vw);
```

This ensures:
- **Minimum 12px padding** on desktop for comfortable reading
- **2.5vw responsive scaling** that adapts smoothly to viewport width
- **No discrete breakpoints** - continuous responsive behavior

## Changes

Updated `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/media/chatViewWelcome.css`:

- `.chat-welcome-view-disclaimer` (absolutely positioned state)
- `.chat-welcome-view-additional-message` (general styling)  
- `.chat-welcome-view-disclaimer` with chat history
- `.chat-welcome-view-disclaimer` without chat history (added missing padding)

## Testing

- Verified responsive behavior at multiple viewport widths (1280px, 400px, 250px)
- Confirmed consistent spacing across all disclaimer message variants
- Validated no regressions in existing chat welcome states
- Ensured smooth scaling without jarring transitions

The fix provides a better mobile experience while maintaining desktop usability, addressing the padding inconsistency that made disclaimer text difficult to read at narrow widths.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

----
**Additional instructions:**

> Standardize the padding for the empty-chat disclaimers so the lines "AI responses may be inaccurate." and "If handling customer data, disable telemetry." always have identical, smoothly responsive spacing at narrow widths. apply a fix so padding doesn't jump only at discrete breakpoints

Fixes microsoft/vscode#267430

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->

title: Fix overlapping text in chat panel empty state with minimal CSS change
body:
Fixes overlapping disclaimer texts in the Chat panel empty state when `chat.emptyState.history.enabled` and/or `chat.promptFilesRecommendations` are enabled at small side-panel widths.

## Problem

When the chat panel is narrow (typically in a sidebar), the disclaimer texts "AI responses may be inaccurate" and "Generate instructions to onboard AI onto your codebase" would overlap, making them unreadable. This occurred because both elements used `position: absolute; bottom: 0`, causing them to render in the same position.

![Before: Overlapping text issue](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb637d2f-8cc8-4dca-b135-6dec9190c807)

## Solution

Applied a minimal CSS fix by separating the overlapping elements with different vertical positions:

- **Empty state message**: Positioned at `bottom: 24px` to provide space for the disclaimer below
- **Disclaimer text**: Remains at `bottom: 0` at the bottom of the container

![After: Fixed layout with proper separation](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3843378f-5928-4e9b-94f1-8eac94176962)

## Changes

The fix required only one minimal change in `chatViewWelcome.css`:
- Separated the combined CSS selector `.chat-welcome-view-message.empty-state, .chat-welcome-view-disclaimer` into two individual selectors
- Changed `.chat-welcome-view-message.empty-state` to use `bottom: 24px` instead of `bottom: 0`
- No additional styling, fonts, or responsive behavior changes

This approach keeps the change minimal while solving the core overlapping issue, maintaining all existing VS Code styling conventions and behavior for normal and wide panels.

Tested at narrow widths (250px and 180px) to ensure proper separation without overlap.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

----
**Additional instructions:**

> Fix layout in the Chat panel empty state: when chat.emptyState.history.enabled and/or chat.promptFilesRecommendations are enabled the disclaimer texts ('AI responses may be inaccurate' and 'Generate instructions...'/ 'If handling customer data, disable telemetry') overlap at small side-panel widths. Make the empty-state responsive so those disclaimer elements never overlap: allow text to wrap and stack vertically at narrow widths. Keep changes minimal, follow existing VS Code styling conventions, and update the empty-state CSS/component.

Fixes microsoft/vscode#265071

body: The new macOS broker flow when signing in to Microsoft, pops this native window: (not showing all of it because of emails) You can see in the title, it says "Code - Insiders Helper (Plugin)" this is a little wordy.... it probably should say "Code - Insiders" instead. This is apparently defined here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-gulp-electron/blob/c48d7a5d65e707a424a95c78d2dec0aad1edb162/src/darwin.js#L254-L258 We could consider changing this to `infoPlist["CFBundleDisplayName"] = opts.productName` With that said @deepak1556 had some concerns with doing this... mainly macOS behaving differently when setting this setting. It may have more power than simply changing the title of notifications. Because of this, and because this will only be visible by a fraction of users, we're opting to not do anything for right now... but we could consider experimenting with this in the future.

title: MCP Integration broken
body:
Type: Bug Bug Report: Tools not visible in chat after restart, even though MCP server is running Summary I am running an MCP server in a Docker container on localhost. Until recently, VS Code MCP integration worked fine: the server connected, tools were discovered, and I could use them in chat. After a restart, something broke: - The server runs correctly (health check returns 200 OK). - VS Code output panel shows that the server is detected and tools are discovered. - But inside the chat, no tools are available. Evidence VS Code MCP Server output 2025-09-22 22:37:37.218 [info] Starting server Cognite_GraphTraversal_LocalDocker 2025-09-22 22:37:37.220 [info] Connection state: Starting 2025-09-22 22:37:37.220 [info] Starting server from LocalProcess extension host 2025-09-22 22:37:37.229 [info] Connection state: Running 2025-09-22 22:37:37.455 [info] Discovered 7 tools Docker logs (simplified) - Uvicorn server starts fine. - /health endpoint returns {"status": "healthy"}. - Tools load successfully on server side. VS Code Chat - No tools are listed or usable. - The assistant responds as if no MCP servers are available. What works - MCP server starts normally in Docker. - curl http://localhost:8000/health → 200 OK. - curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/mcp ... returns valid JSON-RPC responses. - VS Code detects and logs discovered tools. What doesn’t - Tools never show up in the Chat assistant. - Restarting VS Code, reloading windows, or re-associating the server does not fix it. Setup - Host OS: Windows 11 - MCP server: Python + FastMCP running in Docker - Transport: streamable-http - VS Code extension: latest MCP integration - mcp.json entry: { "servers": { "Cognite_GraphTraversal_LocalDocker": { "url": "http://localhost:8000/mcp", "type": "streamable-http" } } } Notes - This worked fine before a Windows restart. - After restart, the server logs still show Discovered 7 tools, but chat ignores them. - Possibly related to session negotiation (initialize / capabilities handshake)? Request Could this be a bug in how VS Code handles re-establishing MCP sessions after a restart? Any guidance on debugging (e.g. forcing re-initialization, clearing MCP session cache) would be appreciated. Also, AFTER I found it not working, I tried to update VS Code (which for some reason was downloading a 'standalone' folder instead of the usual exe. I went to the website, downloaded the latest exe and installed. The issue didn't go away. ``` 2025-09-22 22:37:37.218 [info] Starting server Cognite_GraphTraversal_LocalDocker 2025-09-22 22:37:37.220 [info] Connection state: Starting 2025-09-22 22:37:37.220 [info] Starting server from LocalProcess extension host 2025-09-22 22:37:37.229 [info] Connection state: Running 2025-09-22 22:37:37.455 [info] Discovered 7 tools ``` VS Code version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: GPT-5 Appears Slower in Time to Complete a Turn in 1.104.0, Possibly due to TODO tool addition
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: 1.104.1
- OS Version:
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT-5 
- Logs:

According to the telemetry, GPT-5 looks to be taking about 30% longer to complete a turn than it did in the previous stable build. Our initial hypothesis is that this has something to do with the todo tool being added to GPT-5, but interestingly GPT-5-mini does not show the same change. We are following up with additional analyses on the telemetry to understand the role the todo tool might be playing. 

@isidorn

title: Terminal text duplicates when resizing height; cls command does not work

labels.name: upstream
labels.description: Issue identified as 'upstream' component related (exists outside of VS Code)

labels.name: windows
labels.description: VS Code on Windows issues

labels.name: terminal-conpty
labels.description: Integrated terminal issues related to the ConPTY backend

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.401.1
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code.
2. Open the integrated terminal
3. Run any command to generate visible output.
4. Hover over the top border of the terminal panel until the resize cursor appears.
5. Click and drag the terminal up or down to change its height several times, then look at the previous lines.
6. Observe that existing lines in the terminal are duplicated multiple times across the viewport.
7. Attempt to run the cls command
8. Notice that the terminal content does not clear cls appears to have no effect

No such artifacts are seen in the Windows Terminal on the same computer.

I previously opened a ticket related to the problem in the vscode terminal, but they told me that the problem was not in vscode, although everything points to the opposite:

"Terminal text duplicates when resizing height; cls command does not work #267477"

I tried to reproduce the bug on another device with Windows 11 with the latest current system update and the bug still recurred, while on the device with Windows 10 on which this bug was initially detected, such errors do not occur in the standard terminal.

The previous ticket contains screenshots reproducing the bug on Windows 10, but I can also attach screenshots reproducing the bug on Windows 11 if needed.
The bug also repeats on this set:
VS Code version: Code 1.104.1
OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045

title: Fix history list not updating when deleting chats from command palette
body:
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264521
Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/266407

*Note: See video in comment below showing changes.

The History preview in the Chat view panel was not reactively updating when a chat was removed from the Workspace Chat History command palette. Users would delete a chat session from the command palette, but the deleted item would still appear in the history preview until the panel was refreshed manually.

## Root Cause

The ChatWidget renders the history list statically and had no mechanism to detect when history entries were removed via the command palette. While the command palette correctly called `chatService.removeHistoryEntry()` and refreshed its own picker items, the ChatWidget's history list remained stale.

## Solution

Implemented an event-driven approach using VS Code's existing event architecture:

1. **Added `onDidRemoveHistoryEntry` event** to the `IChatService` interface
2. **Modified `ChatService.removeHistoryEntry()`** to emit the event after successful deletion
3. **Added event listener in ChatWidget** constructor to call existing `refreshHistoryList()` method
4. **Updated MockChatService** for test compatibility

## Implementation Details

```typescript
// Service fires event when history entry is removed
async removeHistoryEntry(sessionId: string): Promise<void> {
    await this._chatSessionStore.deleteSession(sessionId);
    this._onDidRemoveHistoryEntry.fire({ sessionId });
}

// ChatWidget listens and refreshes automatically  
this._register(this.chatService.onDidRemoveHistoryEntry(() => this.refreshHistoryList()));
```

## Testing

The fix can be verified by:
1. Creating chat sessions with history entries
2. Opening the Chat view panel to see the history preview
3. Deleting a visible chat via Command Palette → "Workspace Chat History"
4. Confirming the history preview updates immediately without manual refresh

This minimal change (4 files, 9 lines added) provides reactive updates while maintaining existing functionality and following VS Code's event-driven patterns.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

----
**Additional instructions:**

> Please update the History preview in the Chat view panel to reactively update when a chat is removed in the Workspace Chat History command palette.
> 
> If a chat menu item in the Workspace Chat History command palette is removed, and that item happens to be rendered in the History preview in the chat view panel it should be removed as well.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

title: Fix chat welcome history tooltip positioning to prevent overlap with other UI elements

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

body:
Fixes an issue where tooltips for chat history items in the welcome view were overlapping with other items in the list, creating a poor user experience. The tooltip placement now properly adapts based on the panel location, similar to how tooltips work in the file explorer.

## Problem

Chat welcome history tooltips were appearing with fixed positioning that caused them to overlap with adjacent list items and other UI elements, making the interface difficult to use when hovering over truncated chat session titles.

![Before fix showing overlapping tooltips](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4fa0cccf-4776-4c79-837e-64072ebcdee5)

## Solution

Implemented position-aware tooltips that respect VS Code's panel layout system:

- **Sidebar panels**: Tooltips appear on the opposite side of the sidebar (left sidebar → right tooltips, right sidebar → left tooltips)
- **Auxiliary bar panels**: Tooltips appear on the same side as the sidebar position  
- **Bottom panel**: Tooltips appear to the right (default behavior)

## Implementation

1. **Created `ChatHistoryHoverDelegate`** - A specialized hover delegate extending `WorkbenchHoverDelegate` that determines tooltip positioning based on the current view container location and sidebar position.

2. **Enhanced `ChatHistoryListRenderer`** - Added tooltip support to chat history list items using the hover service with the position-aware delegate.

3. **Integrated existing layout services** - Leveraged the existing `ChatContextKeys.panelLocation` context key and `IWorkbenchLayoutService` to determine the current panel configuration.

4. **Added CSS styling** - Included `.chat-history-item-hover` class for consistent tooltip appearance with proper max-width and word-wrapping.

The implementation follows the exact same positioning logic as VS Code's SCM history view tooltips, ensuring consistency across the application.

## Testing

- Verified tooltip positioning logic with all layout combinations
- Confirmed compilation success with no TypeScript errors
- Implementation matches existing VS Code tooltip patterns for position-aware behavior

Fixes microsoft/vscode#<issue_number>

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

----
**Additional instructions:**

> Tooltip placement for empty state history list items should be dependent on whether the view is in the primary or secondary panel; just like the tooltip hover for files in the filetree in the File Explorer panel.

Fixes microsoft/vscode#266373

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

title: [Accessbility] Screen reader is not announcing tooltip on focus/hover of "Search Workspace" button

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
# PROBLEM:
The screen reader is not announcing the value of the text that appears in the tooltip that appears on focus/hover of the "Search Workspace" button in the `.monaco-action-bar`. It only announces the text value of the button itself.

## OBSERVED RESULTS:
When the "<Search icon> Workspace" button in the `.monaco-action-bar` is focused or hovered when the screen reader is enabled, the screen reader does NOT announce the text of the tooltip that pops up "Search Workspace ---- Welcome - Workspace - Visual Studio Code". 
* In **Chromebook + ChromeVox** it is reading "Workspace Button Toolbar, Press search plus space to activate." 
* This also is the case with a **Mac + VoiceOver,** it reads "Workspace Button, You are currently on a toolbar, inside of a toolbar."

## EXPECTED RESULTS:
On focus/hover of the "Search Workspace" button in the `.monaco-action-bar`, the text value of the tooltip that appears should be announced by the screen reader for screen reader users.

## USER IMPACT:
Ensure that additional content that appears and disappears in response to a hover state is perceivable and supports certain interaction requirements.

## STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
1. Go to [VSCode Dev](https://vscode.dev/)
2. Enable your screen reader.
3. Focus on hover on the "Search Workspace" button in the `.monaco-action-bar`/toolbar at the top of VSCode.
4. Observe the tooltip text that appears on focus/hover and that there is no screen reader announcement of that tooltip text.

## ENVIRONMENT DETAILS:
* Machine: Chromebook
Browser: Version 136.0.7103.158 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Accessibility Tool: ChromeVox.

* Machine: MacBook Pro
Browser: Version 137.0.7151.104 (Official Build) (arm64)
Accessibility Tool: VoiceOver.

title: Support fully qualified tool names in .chatmode.md files
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently [`.chatmode.md`](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/customization/custom-chat-modes#_chat-mode-file-example) can only specify tool names. If there are two MCP servers that provide the same tool name, the filter will always enable both of them. That requires manually disabling unwanted servers/tools in the settings and the result is not preserved after VSCode relaunch. It should be possible to specify fully qualified tool name that includes the MCP label. Similar to how they seem to be [keyed internally](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/90768f866c683cd6d6fde4eb2a7425ffdbe5c017/src/vs/workbench/contrib/mcp/common/mcpService.ts#L226-L233).

Needed in Playwright to avoid collision between Playwright test and Playwright MCP that the users may have preinstalled.

title: Include a software statement in the dynamic client registration payload

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
On the topic of software statements, I have been thinking about how to design this for VS Code... an interesting scenario considering:
* it's a public client so verification of the client is limited
* It's open source so there are forks

Since VS Code _is_ a public client, we often leverage `https://vscode.dev` for any service-related operations. So my thinking is that we can leverage this domain to host our software statement related endpoints. The goal is to support VS Code's DCR flow... while also preventing accidental usage of these endpoints from forks or other clients... while also setting us up for success for supporting CIMD. Here are the 3 routes I am thinking about:

```
vscode.dev/
/.well-known/jwks.json - returns what you expect, the JWKS for verifying software statements
/software-statement - returns the software statement that VS Code should use
/dcr - returns the DCR payload that VS Code should send
```

I want to introduce some complexity to `/software-statement` just to prevent accidental usage of this endpoint. I know today, I can't prevent intentional usage without doing some crazy client assertation stuff... That's out of scope for now.

This complexity needs to satisfy two requirements:
1. It needs some sort of input from the client to generate the software statement... this way someone can't just hit the endpoint without any input and get a valid software statement
2. The payload itself can't be the input (in other words, making the route completely stateless). We should only generate software statements for payloads we expect... but we should only have a single source of truth for what that payload is.

So with this in mind, my thinking is that the VS Code publishing pipeline (which would only be run for official VS Code builds) will call `/dcr` to first get the DCR payload and embed that in the build along with the URL to mint a software statement (`https://vscode.dev/software-statement`). This satisfies requirement `#2` because we have a single source of truth for the DCR payload. It also prevents accidental usage (from forks) because the payload & URL is not embedded until publish time.

Then, at runtime, when VS Code wants to do a DCR, it will first call `/software-statement` with a hash of the DCR payload it has embedded. This satisfies requirement `#1` because the client has to provide some input to get a valid software statement... in this case the hash of the DCR payload. The server can then verify that the hash matches the expected hash of one of the valid DCR payloads it has at the source of truth. If it matches, it can mint a software statement and return it. If it doesn't match, it can return a 400.

Lastly, we expose the `/.well-known/jwks.json` endpoint so that authorization servers can verify the software statement.

Like I said, this isn't preventing intentional usage. Afterall, I am explaining how it works here... but it does prevent any accidental usage from forks or other clients because some hoops need to be jumped through to get a valid software statement.

But this might be overcomplicating things... I'd love to hear thoughts.

title: Add horizontal tab bar for terminals in a standalone window

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
The August 2025 release notes highlighted improvements to [terminal window discoverability](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_104#_terminal-window-discoverability-and-polish), which is great!

However, when multiple terminals are opened in a separate window (using the **+** button at the top), the previously opened terminals appear to vanish, with no clear indication that more than one terminal exists in that window.

What actually happens is confusing: the terminal tabs for a stand-alone window show up in the main VS Code window instead. Related issue (possibly worth a separate report): changing window-specific settings—such as hiding the status bar in the stand-alone terminal window—also hides the status bar in the main VS Code editor window.

**Expected behavior:**

* The stand-alone terminal window should display its own horizontal row of tabs (ideally integrated into the top title bar).
* Hiding the status bar in the stand-alone terminal window should only affect that window, not the main editor window.

**Request:** Please add a dedicated tab bar and independent status bar visibility for stand-alone terminal windows.

title: [WIP] get_task_output says "task finished" when task is still running
body:
## Fix misleading "task finished" message for watching tasks

The issue: `get_task_output` tool displays "task finished" for watching tasks that are still actively running, which misleads users.

### Root Cause
- The `toolResultMessageFromResponse()` function only checked if terminals were idle (`OutputMonitorState.Idle`)
- For watching tasks, terminals can be idle between file changes but the task is still actively watching
- This caused watching tasks to show "finished" when they were actually still running

### Solution
- Modified `toolResultMessageFromResponse()` to accept an optional `isTaskStillActive` parameter
- Updated logic to check both terminal state AND task activity: task is only "finished" if terminals are idle AND task is not active
- Updated both `getTaskOutputTool` and `createAndRunTaskTool` to check task activity using existing `_isTaskActive()` method
- Maintained backward compatibility for when `isTaskStillActive` is not provided

### Changes Made
- [x] Analyze the codebase and understand the issue
- [x] Add `isTaskStillActive` parameter to `toolResultMessageFromResponse()` function  
- [x] Update task activity logic to distinguish truly finished vs actively watching tasks
- [x] Update both `getTaskOutputTool.ts` and `createAndRunTaskTool.ts` to pass task activity
- [x] Add comprehensive tests covering the new behavior and backward compatibility
- [x] Verify compilation and security checks pass

### Key Files Modified
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/tools/task/taskHelpers.ts` - Updated message logic
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/tools/task/getTaskOutputTool.ts` - Pass task activity  
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/tools/task/createAndRunTaskTool.ts` - Pass task activity
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/test/browser/taskHelpers.test.ts` - Tests for new behavior

### Expected Result
- Watching tasks will now show "started and will continue to run in the background" instead of "finished"
- Truly finished tasks will continue to show "finished" as before
- Backward compatibility maintained for existing callers

title: reduce memory by ~1.2 MB
body: ### Overview This changes the `toDisposable` function to use a class so that there is one dispose function on the class prototype instead of a dispose closure created for each `toDisposable` function call. The memory savings seem to be ~1.2 MB. ### Function overview chart This function overview chart of vscode shows how many function instances exist of each function: ![base](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/60588385-ad2c-4f9f-be21-f9024e3100cc) Notably at the top is `createSingleCallFunction`, which is used by `toDisposable`. ### Heapsnapshot before ### Heapsnapshot after ### Notable differences: - The number of `Functions` is reduced from 117165 to 96305 - The number of `closures (System Context)` is reduced from 55728 to 35040 - The number of `{ dispose }` objects is reduced from 11342 to 1192 - The number of `FunctionDisposables` increases from 0 to 10087 - The memory savings seem to be ~1.2 MB.

title: Azure Trafficmanager configuration seems to cause vscode download failures

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: upstream
labels.description: Issue identified as 'upstream' component related (exists outside of VS Code)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled? Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: n/a
- OS Version: n/a

Azure Trafficmanager configuration for "sundry-f-net.trafficmanager.net" used in the CNAME chain of vscode downloads "vscode.download.prss.microsoft.com" seems broken for certain DNS source subnets such as 146.108.202.0/24 causing download attempts from these subnets to fail as the CNAME chain ends in a NOERROR response but without any result. This even causes the official vscode download button on https://code.visualstudio.com to end in an error message.

Ping @rzhao271 due to comment at https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/212682#issuecomment-2542349367

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `dig @tm1.edgedns-tm.info sundry-f-net.trafficmanager.net +subnet=146.108.202.0/24`
2. Compare to: `dig @tm1.edgedns-tm.info sundry-f-net.trafficmanager.net +subnet=146.108.200.0/24` (or any other non-affected subnet)

Mapping for the /16:
146.108.0.0/17: download.prss.microsoft.com.akamaized.net.
146.108.128.0/18: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.
146.108.192.0/21: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.
146.108.200.0/23: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.
146.108.202.0/24: **no mapping - NOERROR empty response**
146.108.203.0/24: download.prss.microsoft.com.akamaized.net.
146.108.204.0/22: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.
146.108.208.0/20: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.
146.108.224.0/19: fg.microsoft.map.fastly.net.

This seems to have initially appeared somewhere around May this year or even earlier; I last investigated this on August 13th and by today that issue is still present so it doesn't look like it's something temporary.

Not sure if this is intentional, how many subnets are affected in total - and where to report..
Sorry if this is the wrong communication channel.

title: Edits should be presented in order
body:
When Copilot makes multiple edits in a long file, I might scroll up and forget to click above the edit before accepting it. 

I would expect the file to scroll to the next edit, but instead it scrolls to the next edit after the cursor (which might be all the way to the end of the file). This makes it harder accept edits in order.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Request a multi-edit change in Agent mode in a long file
2. Place the cursor in the middle of the file
3. Scroll to the first edit and click the keep checkmark ✅ 

Expected behavior:
The second edit should come into view

Actual behavior:
The edit after the cursor comes into view

title: Auto should recommend models when I have not configured a model's policy
body: Auto respects my model policies. However, there may be cases where admins or users leave the model policy as "unconfigured", which is neither explicitly enabled or disabled. This could be due to missing a model availability announcement or related. In some cases, Copilot gracefully nudges users to enable models that they have not yet configured. In other cases, an error is thrown that is not immediately clear whether there's an issue with my policies, Auto, or Copilot. **Request** Auto gracefully nudges me to enable models I haven't configured. Example: Current experience with errors: In this scenario, I did not configure GPT 5 use.

Copilot is active and responding to your requests in this chat window, including for your Readme.md file. If you want Copilot to generate code completions directly in the editor (inline suggestions), make sure the Copilot extension is installed and enabled. For chat-based help, you are already connected and Copilot is active. Restore Checkpoint how to force triggering it from the Readme.md? To trigger GitHub Copilot inline suggestions in Readme.md: Start typing a comment, code block, or Markdown content. Press Tab to accept Copilot’s suggestion if it appears. If no suggestion appears, press Ctrl+Enter (Linux) or Cmd+Enter (Mac) to manually request a Copilot completion. You can also use Alt+\ to trigger Copilot inline suggestions. If Copilot is enabled, these actions will prompt it to generate content directly in your editor. Manual Trigger: Use Ctrl+Enter (Linux) or Cmd+Enter (Mac) to manually request a suggestion. File Type Support: Copilot works best in code files. In Markdown files, suggestions may be less frequent. Try typing a comment or code block to increase suggestion likelihood. Restart VS Code: Sometimes, restarting VS Code or reloading the window helps. Check Internet Connection: Copilot requires an active internet connection. Sign In: Make sure you are signed in to GitHub in VS Code. title: Chat: Sending a message before Chat is ready won't select the previously selected model
body:

2. Reload.
3. Before Chat is ready, send a message.
